elements.text: [Part One]
Mrs Mapp? Mrs Mapp! Oh, there you are. You shouldn't have strayed so far alone. You could have...
I'm perfectly capable of taking care of myself, Mister Von Thal.
Rupert, please. Well, perhaps you are strolling about in Bloomsbury, my dear, but this is my element, the jungle wilderness.
The empty wilderness. That machete of yours would be better employed in cutting us some more firewood rather than acting as a rapier to protect me.
This is an exceedingly hostile environment.
So are the literary salons of London, Mister Von Thal, believe me.
What was that?
Nothing. Now, help me with this branch. I think it...
Roar.
What in the name of...?
Dear God in Heaven! It must be twelve feet high. Well, fourteen, perhaps.
Don't just stand there calculating its height, kill it!
What? Oh yes, at once.
Clang.
It's no good. My blade simply rebounds off its chitinous hide.
Its chitinous hide? Stab it in the eye, for heaven's sake!
Stab it?
In the eye!
Take that!
Roar.
Look out!
Rupert cries out. Roar then silence.
Mister Von Thal? Mister Von Thal?
Dragging sound..
Are you all right?
Yeah, I'm fine. If a little nauseous.
I'm not surprised. That creature's blood smells like Billingsgate. Give me your hand.
Thank you. Thank you.
By Jove! It snapped my machete. What do you think it was? Some giant locust or a mantis, perhaps?
I've no idea. Have you ever seen the like in your travels?
Never. And I've explored the most inaccessible corners of our world, experienced the most terrible things, like when I was taken up the Limpopo by the natives.
Come along, Rupert. Let's get back to the others. It's hard to tell, what with the sky being that rather outré shade of mauve, but I think that night is approaching. This way.
Do you think he's right after all?
Who's right?
That man. He said we'd gone back in time, that this was some evil period in our world's distant history.
That man has got some stiff questions coming his way. Bringing us here, what was he thinking?
Never mind what he was thinking. How did he do it? That's the question that's troubling me.
And why?
Precisely. Seemed just a lark at first.

I took it very seriously. Somehow I knew his experiment would succeed. From the first moment when we were all assembled in my sitting-room, I knew it would be a success. You see, Mister Von Thal, even then I believed in him. That man, the Doctor.
General conversation. Tapping on glass.
I say. Hello? Hello?
Someone shushes the gathering.
Er, yes. Er, good morning, everyone. I'm the Doctor. Thank you all for coming, and - and thank you, Mrs Mapp, for allowing me to use your sitting-room for my experiment.
I'm sure we're all rather intrigued, Doctor, by what you hope to achieve during this experiment of
yours.
None more so than me.
Thank you, Nyssa. Let's just see what happens, shall we?
Very well. Do get on with it, will you?
Please, Professor, have patience.
What the devil...? Mrs Mapp, your maidservant is lecturing me on temperance.
Maidservant?
Miss Nyssa is the Doctor's assistant, Professor Quandry.
Assistant?
Er - research associate, actually.
Better.
Look, shall we get on?
So how does it work, then, eh? Kind of a séance thing, is it? Table-rapper, is it, Mrs Mapp?
Wait and see, Mister Von Thal.
Not a séance, no. No, something I hope you will find much more interesting. You're all here, some of the finest minds in the Empire, to lend your mental weight to a unique experiment.
Finest minds, eh? Huh. I'm just a humble explorer, old man. I'm only here because I'm a friend of the vexatious Professor Quandry.
We needed twelve. We were two short.
We're just making up the numbers, Mister Von Thal.
If I'm number eleven, who, pray, is number twelve?
Door opens.
Ah. Brenda. Right on cue.
Will you be wanting the tea now, madam?
No, Brenda, stop that at once, we're embarking on an experiment and we need you to assist.
Desist, Madam? I've not started yet.
Er, here. Sit down, Brenda, you can fill the gap next to Professor Quandry.
Help make up the numbers.
Sit, girl.
Yes, ma'am.
Finally we are a quorum. Correct, Doctor?
Correct. Now, I want you all to link hands around the table. Mrs Mapp, if you wouldn't mind. That's it. And Mister Von Thal, hold hands with Nyssa, and all the rest of you.
Hold hands, yes, yes, good grief.
Until all twelve of us are joined as one.
Well, I don't mind holding the hand of a lovely lady.
There's no need to grip, Mister Von Thal.
Now, I need you to concentrate. I'm about to say a series of numbers, and I want you to repeat them out loud. Then I want you to let yourselves sink into a trance.
But what for, Doctor? What are we hoping to achieve?
Transference, Mrs Mapp. Now, you keep repeating 0001. Mister Von Thal...
... you say 0110, and Professor Quandry...
... 1110. And Brenda...
Voices blend, a humming.
Doctor, something is not right. Block Transfer Computation is never this quick.
I agree, Nyssa. Everyone, stop! The experiment's gone wrong...!
Echoing and fading.
Nysa gasps for breath.
Welcome to my city.
Who - who are you?
A friend. A very old friend.
What do you want with me?
You left me. Now I'm calling you back. Will you come, Nyssa?
NYSSA gasps.
Nyssa? Are you all right? Were you having a bad dream?
There's something out there, someone, waiting for us.
It's just an after-echo of the computations, I expect.
No, Doctor, this was different. I saw a city, down there in the valley. I was inside it.
Interesting. You didn't happen to detect the Tardis anywhere on your astral travels, did you?
I don't think it's the Tardis that's drawn us here. It's something else.
You may be right. Someone or something's knocked us off-course, certainly. I sensed it during the séance. Something nagging at me, pulling me back.
The fire's getting low. Where are the others?
Mrs Mapp went off in search of wood, and Mister Von Thal took it upon himself to act as her escort.
I expect the sparks are already flying. Are you going to tell them, Beatrice and Rupert, that it's gone wrong?
From their point of view I suppose we've been successful. I've given them a glimpse of their prehistoric past.
Buzz.
Ow!
Doctor?
Nothing. I'm just being bitten to bits by these insect things.
It's probably the fire that's bringing them in.
Moths to a flame - I know. Ow! Why aren't you being bitten?
You must taste nicer. (echoes)
Madam Teegarna, the whole valley is seething with word of new arrivals. Foul, soft-bodied things.
I do not like it, Kranlee. They threaten our equilibrium, disturb our precious calculations.
Then I say destroy them.
Click, click.
Crush them in our pincers before they cause further upset.
No. Take a patrol up to the heath. Find these soft-bodies and bring them here.
If that is what the Hierarchy demands, madam. I assume Lohkaar is aware of these developments?
Nothing escapes Lohkaar. He sits at the very heart of our web of intelligence, does he not? He senses each and every twitch in our city and the valley beyond. Now, go.
As you command, Madam Teegarna.
And Kranlee? Your place in the calculations is but a small one. Always remember that.
Yes, Madam Teegarna.
Putting wood to the fire.
There. That ought to... (coughs) get her going.
(coughs) I think that's plenty now, Mister Von Thal.
Rupert, my dear. Rupert.
Well? What do you propose to do about it, Doctor?
Do about what, Mrs Mapp?
Getting us home again. I've had quite enough of this benighted place with its giant manti.
I believe the correct plural is mantises.
I shall ignore that. And we'd like to return to West 1, please, tout de suite.
That might be a problem.
You mean you can't do your fancy magic trick again to get us home?
How many more times? It wasn't magic.
Well, if it wasn't magic, what was it?
Remember those numbers the Doctor told you to repeat, as we all sat there?
Some kind of meditative exercise, I presume, like those fakir chaps get up to.
What you were doing was a form of Block Transfer Computation. Now, I don't understand it half as well as the Doctor does...
But you're doing very well, Nyssa. Carry on.

But it's a way of making real things happen in the world through the power of numbers and mathematics. Our universe is fashioned out of raw probability, and the numbers run very deeply into the fabric of our various realities. By altering the numbers...
We alter reality? Yes, I can sort of see that.
Still seems like a lot of hoo-hah to me, but go on. You thought us back through time by having us mumble all these numbers.
The computations allowed me to access the Space-Time continuum in a very limited way. I was hoping to skirt the outer layers and pick up a trace of the flight of my ship, the Tardis.
Now I'm completely lost.
We have a Time and Space machine, but it was stolen.
By whom? A time thief?
A street urchin, actually, name of Thomas Brewster. Anyway, the thing is, the experiment was rather more successful than I anticipated. Somehow for some reason the computations brought us here.
But in order to get us here, it took the combined concentration of a full twelve of us.
But surely you have the necessary skill to take us back?
Not with only four of us, I'm afraid.
So where are the rest of them? Quandry and the others?
They broke the circle, they must have, out of fear or panic.
That's why there are only four of us.
So the rest are back in Bloomsbury?
If they're not adrift in Time and Space.
Not a pleasant thought, Nyssa.
This'll be down to Brenda, I expect, my maid. Most unreliable. I'll have a word with the agency when I get back.
Let me get this straight. Are you saying that we're stuck here, for ever?
Kranlee's soldiers will not fail, Lohkaar.
I hope not, Madam Teegarna. I am most intrigued by these soft-bodied freaks.
And is His Excellency also intrigued? I take it that's where you're scuttling off to.
You should know better than to ask such a frivolous question.
And I'd have thought you'd have been more interested in His Excellency's reactions, Lohkaar. These visitors stand on two legs. Doesn't that make you curious?
It isn't our job to be curious. We are here to serve His Excellency and to maintain the calculations.
We thought our Excellency was unique in the world, did we not? A creature worthy of ruling over us all and telling us what to do?
Careful, Teegarna. You speak treason.
Did you never think it odd that we selected a member of another species to rule over us? A mammal?
This is how it has been for a long time, and his reign has been most excellent.
But we have never seen others like His Excellency before. Perhaps they are just as excellent. Or even more excellent than he is.
You go too far, Madam Teegarna.
Do not raise your pincer to me, Lohkaar. Like most of our hierarchy you are stuck in your ways, thinking nothing will ever change, but it will, Lohkaar, and you won't be ready for it.
I won't have to be, for nothing will have changed. The calculations maintain the equilibrium perfectly. They maintain us in a state of perpetual excellence.
For now.
Madam Teegarna, you would do well to conceal that sardonic edge to your voice. It smacks of insubordination.
Does it? Oh, surely not.
Be mindful of your place in the hierarchy, Teegarna. Now, I have kept His Excellency waiting long enough. (leaves)
Oh, but I am, Lohkaar. I’m very mindful of my place.
Nyssa? Where are you, Nyssa?
Over here.
Are you all right?
I came to admire the view, and to clear my head.
Ah. Our Victorian friends getting you down, are they?

They should be glad you've brought them here and shown them this. You've brought them somewhere no one else could, and look at it. It's beautiful. Cycads, tree ferns, podocarps - and all they want to do is go home.
They're just scared. This is all unknown to them. They like to control things, tame them, make them their own. That's what they were like in their own place and time.

I've spent a little while in their century, and I'm glad to be out of it. All these Victorians, pretending they're so civilised, and all the while enslaving and exploiting the rest of their world, filling it with foul, choking fumes, making wars, creating inequality.
I know, I know. Listen, have you picked up any more signals from this city of yours?
It's still there, like a whisper in the dark. If I close my eyes and concentrate... It's no good, Doctor, it's too faint.
Well, let me know if it gets any stronger. Now, come on. Rupert and Bea will be wondering where we've got to.
This place is a paradise. It seems a shame it's going to fill up with the ancestors of those two.
Oh, come now, Nyssa. Some of my best friends have been human beings.
Yes, I've never quite understood that.
Nyssa? Are you there? Open your mind to me.
Excellency. Your Excellency.
Oh Lohkaar, you idiot. The link, it's gone. Now... now I'll have to scan the ether all over again.
I apologise, Excellency.
Oh, get up off your abdomen, Lohkaar. What is it you want?
You sent for me, Excellency.
Di...? Wh...? Oh, did I?
Something of the utmost importance. An adjustment to the calculations, perhaps?
Oh. Oh yes, I recall now. It... it's feeding time for my pet. There's a mantis carcass in the drop pot.
Oh, I see. You want this meat dragging ov...
To the pit, yes. I'm not quite strong enough. Oh, she can smell it. Oh, here she comes.
Shall I just throw it down to her?
Please. Ah. Slim pickings today, I'm afraid, pretty one. Ah! Oh, isn't she magnificent? I've always been rather fond of spiders. I have an affinity with them. With all arachnids.
Indeed, Excellency.
Mmm. You look shifty, Lohkaar.
Shifty?
Eager to be elsewhere?
Certainly not, Excellency.
Mmm. What about meeting and questioning the strangers, eh? Are you sure you wouldn't rather be doing that?
Strangers, Excellency?
Bipedal hominids, Lohkaar. Mammalian freaks. Super-advanced apes. Mmm. Thought you'd see them for yourself first, did you, before alerting me?
I... I didn't want to disturb your rest, Excellency. Of late you have been so weary, what with the cares of the day-to-day running of our magnificent city...
You don't give me that. You saw that these strangers were of the same species as me, didn't you? You were intrigued by that.
Your Excellency...
I don't like it. In future I want to know everything that happens here. I may be old, but I still retain all of my faculties. And whatever you may think, I still rule here. This is still my world.
Excellency, do not agitate yourself. In meeting the ape primitives first I hoped merely to spare you the extra work. But if you would rather question and examine them yourself...
Of course I would.
I understand. You are eager to see creatures of your own kind again.
Oh, not just any creatures, Lohkaar. These particular ones. Nyssa and the Doctor.
Fire burning.
I don't like it, Mrs Mapp. We should stick together. You should never split up when you're in the wild.
They haven't been gone long.
What if he and the girl just go whistling off, eh? Summon up some more of that mumbo-jumbo of theirs and simply abandon us here?
Oh, I don't think they'd do that, Mister Von Thal, even if they could.

Huh. Hmm. These crickets are nearly roasted. I think I'll just turn them over. So where did you say you met them, the Doctor and Miss Nyssa? In a tea-shop near the British Museum, wasn't it? Babbling on about the fifth dimension?
Shh! Rupert, did you hear that?
What?
Something moving, in the bushes.
No, nothing. Oh, you called me Rupert.
I panicked.
That makes two of us, Beatrice.
Look, there. Eyes, blazing in the darkness.
Good Lord. And there's more over there. And there.
We're surrounded.
Giant scorpions! Beatrice, behind me.
Here. Torches.
Torches?
To ward them off. Like this.
Oh, excellent, yes. Take that! Hah! And that!
We can't hold out forever against them. These torches will... Oh!
Leave them alone. Get back!
Oh! Thank you, Doctor. I think you frightened them. Look. They're standing back in shock.
I don't think they're in shock, Mrs Mapp. I think they're listening.
Listening? You don't mean to say that they can understand us?
I don't know. Can you? Hmm, most interesting.
Interesting?
Mister Von Thal, we can't defend our camp all night and we can't fight them.
So?
So we have to talk to them.
Always the best way.
Talk to them? Are you mad? How fluent are you in Scorpion?
Listen and learn, Mrs Mapp.
Doctor, be careful.
Oh, I will be, I promise. Good evening. I wonder if I could speak to whoever's in charge. I'd like to call a truce. A parlay. Pow-wow. Confab.
His words heard as if underwater.
What is this gibberish? Perhaps the creature's offering itself as a sacrifice.
They're making an awful noise, Doctor.
Probably they're laughing at you. I can't say I blame them. Most bedamned thing I ever witnessed.
Guards, be ready. If the yellow-haired one steps any closer, destroy him.
It's no good, I'm not getting through.
That settles it, then. The Tardis isn't in this time period. If it were, its telepathic circuits would be translating your words.
Certainly looks that way, doesn't it?
I told you parlay wouldn't work. Brute strength, that's what's needed now. Ah!
You can't take them on, Rupert. There could be any number of those things out there in the dark.
She's right. We must surrender.
Torches back in the fire, everyone. Mister Von Thal?
Oh, very well.
Now, put your hands up.
Come in, Kranlee. The bush telegraph is clear.
[OC]: We have overcome them, Madam Teegarna.
You have done well, Kranlee.
[OC]: We will be back in the city within the hour.
Good. I will sever this connection now. Hurry, Kranlee. His Excellency is keen to see the creatures. As am I.
My fellow arachnids. I, Kraniee, have captured these mammalian freaks in the jungle. Look upon them with disgust.
Just look at it. It's like being inside a monumental Saint Paul's.
Or inside a giant termite hill.
It's certainly quite a place.
How many of them live here, do you think, in this nest?
Millions. But it's not a nest. It's a city.
And the citizens have laid on a parade for us, pincers and all.
Nyssa, is this how it was in your dream?
Yes. Exactly.
Do you mind? We're not cattle.
I rather think that's precisely what we are, Rupert.
How do you mean?
We're being shepherded towards that... tower, I suppose you'd call it.
Cows to the slaughterhouse. Oh, Lord.
Doctor, can you hear it?
Hear what, Nyssa?
The chanting. Zeroes and ones. Listen.
The tune of it. The strange music of it, it's mathematics. Has to be some form of computation.
Yes. And where have we heard that before?
Look lively you two, we're here.
Three knocks.
I crave entrance to the Palace of Excellence. I, Kranlee, have brought the mammalian freaks.
Door opens.
Fall back, Kranlee. I shall lead the escort from here.
But... Madam Teegarna.
Remember your place, Kranlee. Come, captives. His Excellency awaits. Move, you soft-bodied fools.
Sorry, old fella. Don't know what you're on about.
Don't antagonise it, Rupert. It clearly wants you to follow.
None of this should be here. Giant scorpions building cities, it's like some alternative reality. What's happened to the world? Nyssa, you've gone very pale.
Doctor, in my dream, I think I know who it was who spoke to me.
You do?
But it can't be.
Stop. Here are the captives, Lohkaar.
Thank you, Madam Teegarna. Excellency? Your Excellency? They have been brought to you, as you demanded.
Here we go. Scorpion King.
But - it's a man.
Great Scott. Methuselah.
At last. At last you're here. I knew you'd come in the end, Doctor.
Doctor, do you know this old buffer?
I... I don't believe it.
It's him. It's really him.
Adric?

BEATRICE: I took it very seriously. Somehow I knew his experiment would succeed. From the first moment when we were all assembled in my sitting-room, I knew it would be a success. You see, Mister Von Thal, even then I believed in him. That man, the Doctor.
DOCTOR: I say. Hello? Hello?
DOCTOR: Er, yes. Er, good morning, everyone. I'm the Doctor. Thank you all for coming, and - and thank you, Mrs Mapp, for allowing me to use your sitting-room for my experiment.

NYSSA: None more so than me.

NYSSA: Better.

BEATRICE: We're just making up the numbers, Mister Von Thal.
RUPERT: If I'm number eleven, who, pray, is number twelve?
BEATRICE: Ah. Brenda. Right on cue.
BRENDA: Will you be wanting the tea now, madam?
BEATRICE: No, Brenda, stop that at once, we're embarking on an experiment and we need you to assist.
BRENDA: Desist, Madam? I've not started yet.
DOCTOR: Er, here. Sit down, Brenda, you can fill the gap next to Professor Quandry.
QUANDRY: Help make up the numbers.
BEATRICE: Sit, girl.
BRENDA: Yes, ma'am.
BEATRICE: Finally we are a quorum. Correct, Doctor?
